article.description: Utah got a scare from UNLV but Tim Frost sparked the Utes (No. 23 AP) to an overtime win.
article.headline: Rebels scare Utes, but Frost handles matters in OT
article.linkText: Frost gets busy inside to lift Utes past UNLV
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Utah got a scare from UNLV but Tim Frost sparked the Utes (No. 23 AP) to an overtime win. "I wanted to come out aggressive and demand the ball as we went to overtime. The guys looked to me inside,'' said Frost, who scored 22 points as Utah beat UNLV 86-80 Monday night, winning their Mountain West-record eighth straight conference game. Frost, who tied his career high for points set before transferring from Portland State, scored the first basket of overtime and was fouled, adding a free throw. He converted another three-point play after a dunk and Tim Drisdom added a long 3-pointer to make it 76-70 with 2:34 remaining. "No one expected me to drive hard like that so I just took it to the hoop strong,'' Frost said. Frost's versatility cause problems for the Rebels. "Frost is a bad matchup for us,'' UNLV coach Charlie Spoonhour said. "He's big inside but he can also get out on the floor and shoot. He really hurt us in the overtime.'' Drisdom also hurt the rebels. The freshman point guard scored a career-high 17, was 4-for-4 from the field and 6-of-6 from the line as the Utes (20-4, 8-1) sank eight free throws in a row in the last minute to seal the victory. Marcus Banks scored 30 points and Dalron Johnson added 20 for the Rebels (15-8, 4-5). "We played our hearts out tonight. It's tough to get a win here, you can't give them anything like we did at the start of overtime,'' Banks said. Nick Jacobson scored 14 points and Britton Johnsen had 12 as the Utes won for the 15th time in their last 16 games. Utah is in the Top 25 for the first time since Dec. 4, 2000, just after coach Rick Majerus left the team for personal reasons for the remainder of that season. "We never let down,'' Majerus said. "We sustained our effort all night.'' Trace Caton made a 3-pointer from the corner with 25.9 seconds left in regulation to give Utah a 67-65 lead before Banks made a pair of free throws with 1.8 seconds remaining to force overtime. Utah led 56-42 with 9:21 remaining with Banks and center J.K. Edwards sitting on UNLV's bench with foul trouble. But Ernest Turner and Johnson sparked a 21-4 run over the next 6:08 with four quick points each. Banks returned during the surge and capped it with a 3-pointer to give UNLV a 63-60 lead, its first since the first half. "To come back from 14 down, against a team that's playing as well as Utah is, made me very proud,'' Spoonhour said. Despite being outrebounded 34-27, the Utes improved their home record to 13-0 this season. The game was the first home overtime game since Jan. 18, 1996, an 86-82 win in double overtime against Colorado State.
